org.macquarie.philosophy.animated
Class Philosopher

java.lang.Object
  java.lang.Thread
      org.macquarie.philosophy.animated.Philosopher
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Runnable
public class Philosopher
extends java.lang.Thread

Simulate a single philosopher in the dining philosophers example. Each philosopher is a thread which executes the eating behaviour of that individual:

  • Chat for a random period of time.
  • Pick up left chopstick when it becomes available.
  • Chat for a random period of time.
  • Pick up right chopstick when it becomes available.
  • Eat for a random period of time.
  • Put both chopsticks down on the table.
  • REPEAT.

We use explicit ReentrantLock objects to simulate the chopsticks. To pick up a chopstick a philosopher must lock the ReentrantLock used to represent it. If that object is already locked then that philosopher thread will block until the philosopher thread which originally locked that object returns that chopstick to the table by unlocking it again.

We use the Thread.interrupt() mechanism to handle resets of the simulation. If a philosopher thread receives the interrupt signal it drops (unlocks) both of its chopsticks and restarts the eating process. To make this work properly when a philosopher is blocked waiting for a chopstick to become available, we use the ReentrantLock.lockInterruptibly() method to lock our chopstick objects.

Author:
Dominic Verity

Field Detail

PAUSE

private static final int PAUSE
The standard pause length. The random times which philosophers take to talk or eat food are scaled by this factor. So the bigger we make this the slower the simulation will run.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

sNextNum

private static int sNextNum
A counter used to assign a unique identification number to each philosopher.

mGenerator

private java.util.Random mGenerator
A random number generator used to generate randomly selected pausing periods for talking and eating.

mLeft

private java.util.concurrent.locks.ReentrantLock mLeft
References to the two ReentrantLock objects used to represent the chopsticks to the left and the right of this philosopher.

mRight

private java.util.concurrent.locks.ReentrantLock mRight
References to the two ReentrantLock objects used to represent the chopsticks to the left and the right of this philosopher.

mNum

private int mNum
The identification number of this philosopher.

mHoldingLeft

private volatile boolean mHoldingLeft
Flags which record whether the philosopher is currently holding the left or right chopstick (respectively) in his hands. The value true tells us that a chopstick is currently being held in the given hand and false indicates otherwise.

mHoldingRight

private volatile boolean mHoldingRight
Flags which record whether the philosopher is currently holding the left or right chopstick (respectively) in his hands. The value true tells us that a chopstick is currently being held in the given hand and false indicates otherwise.

Constructor Detail

Philosopher

public Philosopher(java.util.concurrent.locks.ReentrantLock pLeft,
                   java.util.concurrent.locks.ReentrantLock pRight)
When we build a philosopher thread we pass this constructor a pair of references which point to the objects which represent the chopsticks to either side of this philosopher. The new philosopher itself is initialised to a state in which it is not holding anything in either hand.

Parameters:
pLeft - the lock object which represents the chopstick to the left of the new philosopher.
pRight - the lock object which represents the copstick to the right of the new philosopher.

isHoldingLeft

public boolean isHoldingLeft()
Returns:
true if this philosopher is holding a chopstick in his left hand, false otherwise

isHoldingRight

public boolean isHoldingRight()
Returns:
true if this philosopher is holding a chopstick in his right hand, false otherwise
